channel.description: World News: TOI brings the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Vivek Ramaswamy reveals he asked Mark Zuckeberg to apologise about 'censorship'
item.description: Entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy advised Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg to publicly acknowledge past mistakes, particularly banning Trump, to aid national healing in an old interview. Trump disclosed Zuckerberg apologized for censoring his photo. Roivant Sciences founder recalled how he questioned Zuckerberg during a UFC 300 event on the broader implications of societal censorship, particularly in the realm of speech.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: At least nine Palestinians killed as Israel mounts major West Bank operation
Indiana man admits poisoning wife's Coca-Cola to marry her daughter
item.description: Alfred Ruf, a 71-year-old man, admitted to poisoning his wife's Coca-Cola with a toxic substance to kill her and marry her daughter. He pleaded guilty to aggravated battery and was sentenced to four years in prison and five years of probation. The wife tested positive for drugs and reported him to the authorities. ​​​​Ruf explained that the daughter and a female friend would instruct him to spike his wife’s drink, and then they would visit his home to add more of the substance to the drink while she slept.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Afghan women filmed singing in protest of ban on their voices
item.description: Afghan women are protesting an online Taliban law that bans them from raising their voices in public. The new regulation mandates that women must cover their faces, bodies, and voices when outside their homes. Many women, from inside and outside Afghanistan, are defying this law by posting videos of themselves singing on social media.

item.title: South Korea to ask Telegram, other social media firms to help tackle digital sex crimes
item.description: South Korean authorities are pushing Telegram and other social media platforms to aid in the removal of sexually explicit deepfake content. They plan to set up a 24-hour hotline and increase the number of regulatory personnel. The Korea Communications Standards Commission intends to collaborate directly with social media firms for better content moderation.

item.title: California start-up aims to 'sell sunlight' at night; see video
item.description: California-based startup Reflect Orbital plans to extend solar energy availability by reflecting sunlight onto solar panels at night using satellites equipped with mylar mirrors. CEO Ben Nowack presented this innovation at an energy conference in London. The first launch is scheduled for 2025, promising to bridge the energy gap and enhance solar power utilization globally.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Indian students in Canada protest new immigration policies amid deportation fears
item.description: Indian students in Canada are protesting new immigration policies announced by Prime Minister Trudeau’s government. Over 70,000 international students are affected by restrictions on study permits and a reduction in permanent residency nominations. Concerns about deportation and financial instability have grown, with students feeling misled. Temporary foreign worker numbers are also being reduced.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg's leaked video resurfaces amidst censorship accusations: What's the real story?
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Find empty shelves of rice in Japan's supermarkets. What are the causes behind this
item.description: Japan is seeing a rice shortage, with supermarket shelves emptying due to government warnings of a potential megaquake and typhoons. Hot weather has impacted harvests, but the Ministry of Agriculture assures that the situation will improve as new rice is released. Consumers are urged to avoid panic buying and to purchase only necessary amounts.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: THIS airline accidentally sells first-class seats for pennies — Here’s what happened next
item.description: Qantas is addressing a major pricing blunder that led to the sale of first-class tickets at significantly reduced rates. The airline offers affected passengers either a rebooking into business class or a refund. This comes after a recent fine for selling tickets on canceled flights. Customers and observers are closely watching Qantas' response.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: United Airlines faces criticism over flight attendant’s Palestinian flag pin: How company responds amid growing backlash
item.description: A United Airlines flight attendant's display of a Palestinian flag pin and keffiyeh during a flight from Chicago to Newark has drawn criticism. While pro-Israel advocates argue such symbols should be off-duty, the airline maintains its policy permitting flag pins to indicate language skills or personal pride, fostering a broader discussion on political symbols at work.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Is Barron Trump’s college decision in flux? Absence of him and his security at orientation raises questions
item.description: Last week, former President Donald Trump revealed that his son, Barron Trump, will attend a university in New York, deviating from the family's Ivy League tradition. While the school remains undisclosed, Trump cited campus unrest as a factor in the decision. Barron's academic excellence and campus involvement have been praised, adding intrigue.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: One cigarette butt and DNA match: How police decoded decades-old murder mystery
item.description: DNA evidence from a cigarette butt has led to the arrest of 65-year-old Kenneth Kundert for the 1980 rape and murder of Boeing instructor Dorothy Silzel in Kent, Washington. New forensic genealogy technology identified Kundert among potential suspects. He was apprehended following a joint effort with Arkansas authorities and will face charges upon extradition to Washington.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Who is Deadpool killer that kills two Florida women for 'sake of killing'
item.description: Tattooed Deadpool Killer Wade Wilson has been sentenced to death by a Florida court for the 2019 murders of Kristine Melton and Diane Ruiz. The court described the crimes as heinous and premeditated. Despite the brutal nature of his actions, Wilson received numerous letters of support and explicit photographs during his imprisonment.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Watch: IDF rescues father of 11 after 326 days, first successful rescue from Gaza’s tunnels
item.description: The Israeli Defense Forces rescued Qaid Farhan Alkadi from Hamas captivity after 326 days. Alkadi, found in a Hamas tunnel, expressed gratitude to IDF troops and urged the rescue of other hostages. He was taken to Soroka Hospital for evaluation and spoke with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu about the urgency of rescuing others.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Nasa’s Chandra X-ray observatory marks 25 years of unprecedented cosmic discoveries
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US elections: Trump’s economic lead diminishes as GOP aides rally behind Harris, new poll shows
item.description: Vice President Kamala Harris is gaining momentum against former President Donald Trump in the 2024 US presidential race, especially in critical areas like the economy and crime, per recent Reuters/Ipsos polls. Harris's support is growing, bolstered by endorsements from influential former Republican staffers, indicating a significant shift in voter sentiment.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Telegram CEO Pavel Durov’s arrest linked to missing video game streamer Juli Vavilova. Social media trail or honey trap?
item.description: Telegram CEO Pavel Durov was arrested at a Paris airport, coinciding with the mysterious disappearance of 24-year-old streamer Juli Vavilova, who was last seen with him. This unfolding story involves French investigations into serious allegations against Durov, sparking speculation about her role in his capture and their relationship.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: ‘Left in tears’: Meghan Markle struggles with backlash over her lifestyle brand’s debut
item.description: Meghan Markle's American Riviera Orchard, launched in March, is facing hurdles. The brand's inaugural product, strawberry jam, received negative reviews for being overpriced and underwhelming. Despite these challenges, Meghan remains hopeful about her brand's potential and continues to focus on achieving positive reception.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Did Matthew Perry's regrets about his love life contribute to his Ketamine overdose? Here’s what his ex-girlfriend has to say
item.description: Matthew Perry's death in 2021 from a ketamine overdose shocked many. Insights reveal that his emotional struggles were deeply tied to regrets over ending a relationship with Rachel Dunn, whom he considered 'the love of his life.' This loss contributed significantly to his downward spiral into addiction, according to ex-girlfriend Kayti Edwards.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
